The delivery of knowledge, understanding and

117.text:
skills in the theory paper continues to show
good progression for a wide range of ingredients,

components, materials and processes. This

processing and preservation, nutrition and

application. There were a range of levels

a broad and varied distribution of marks across

155.text:

recall, selection, application and communication

Centres need to be aware of the necessity
to prepare candidates for this exam by ensuring

253.text:
that they have a full understanding of the
requirements of different question types:

270.text:
Often, candidates had difficulty in achieving
the full marks for questions asking for an

282.text:
explanation, because answers were not supported
with relevant linked examples or reasoning.

289.text:
Additionally, some of the technical questions
relating to food products and nutritional

295.text:
understanding were incorrect or vague. Centres
must focus on technical understanding, to

302.text:
enable candidates to access the higher marks.
The design question was extremely well received,

310.text:
and significant improvements have been seen
with the quality of sketched and written communication

316.text:
by candidates. Additionally, the extended
writing answers were much better organised,

323.text:
with good planning and use of terminology
presented by candidates.

326.text:
In the short answer questions, candidates
tended to fair better when their answer contained

339.text:
a full sentence with examples where appropriate.
The preparation and processing techniques

352.text:
of ingredients are integral to food technology.
Mixed responses were seen regarding the classification

362.text:
of fish - the majority of candidates knew
about the white and oily fish, but were definitely

363.text:
confused when identifying the shellfish and
crustaceans. This particular response was

365.text:
awarded full marks.
The vast majority of candidates were only

376.text:
awarded 1 mark in this question. They had
a good knowledge of local business and fair-trade,

388.text:
but when asked to quantify it, they couldn't
or didn't know how. The most common responses

394.text:
were to do with local business, fair-trade
and recycling of packaging. However, there

401.text:
was significant confusion that buying from
the local supermarket meant that this supported

407.text:
local business or fair trade, despite the
fact the fruit had been flown into the UK

413.text:
from the other side of the world!

The design question produced some excellent

461.text:
responses from candidates with high quality
sketching and annotation from candidates across

467.text:
the ability range. The link between coursework
activities in the design task was most apparent,

475.text:
with some innovative food product design work.
A wide range of savoury salad products were

482.text:
presented with most candidates managing to
illustrate and label two different ideas.

489.text:
Centres continue to work hard to raise achievement
in this section of the question paper. All

496.text:
examiners noted the continued improvement
in communication techniques and the ability

502.text:
of the candidates to be creative, imaginative
and at times quite inventive with their recipes.

509.text:
Where candidates had read the question carefully
and planned their answer methodically, and

514.text:
sketches and annotation succeeded in showing
how the design had met the specification points,

522.text:
they were rewarded with some high marks. It
is not acceptable to just label the specification

532.text:
points, they must be annotated indicating
how the design has met each point.

537.text:
This was a popular question and the majority
of candidates responded fully. Some of the

547.text:
designs were very good, being fully annotated
and sketched well. There seemed to be a logical

554.text:
process in answering where the candidate had
worked through the specification points one

559.text:
by one.
The point that caused greatest difficulty

563.text:
was regarding value for money. Responses needed
to focus on ways this can be achieved. Therefore

571.text:
correct answers could have referenced that
the food product contained ingredients that

576.text:
were home grown, seasonal or batch produced
to reduce manufacturing costs. Once again,

585.text:
candidates who planned their answers carefully
were rewarded with high marks because they

593.text:
used the specification as a checklist, to
ensure they covered all the points.

595.text:
I will briefly list the main points for consideration
for each specification point.

602.text:
Pastry technique - the most common answer
was puff and shortcrust, but a lot included

612.text:
rubbing-in and folding as the technique.
Finishing technique - this was well answered

620.text:
with the most common response being glazes
(egg/milk) and/or scoring on the outer crust

628.text:
for decoration.
High in protein - well answered by most candidates

636.text:
with meat, cheese, fish and eggs the most
common responses.

641.text:
Suitable for batch production - varied responses
with a lot of candidates gaining 0 marks.

651.text:
When answered correctly standard components
was the most common.

656.text:
High in fibre - well answered with wholemeal
flour or baked beans being the most popular

665.text:
answers. A few candidates put down meat and
fish as including fibre.

671.text:
Easy to transport for a picnic - good responses
for this with most candidates including dimensions

679.text:
or referring to the size of the product with
weight, style and shapes.

686.text:
Value for money - this was not answered well
by candidates and this was the question not

694.text:
answered by a lot of candidates. The most
common answer was local/buy 1 get 1 free (BOGOF).

702.text:
Disappointing responses. % content of protein
to carbohydrate/ and industry discounts such

710.text:
as BOGOF, loyalty schemes at bakery, seasonality
of fruit & veg, weight or portion size compared

721.text:
to cost/, bulk buying ingredients were a few
outstanding responses.

728.text:

responses by candidates with limited knowledge

737.text:
and understanding about ICT uses in food production.
